section.title: Hydrologic Simulation
section.para: There are many alternative definitions of hydrologic simulation that have been used in the literature. For the purposes of this chapter of Australian Rainfall and Runoff, the definition used will be consistent with the conceptual components of a catchment modelling system outlined in ; this definition is that hydrologic modelling is concerned with prediction of the inflow hydrographs entering the catchment drainage system.

It is not possible to define explicitly the point within a catchment where the interface between the hydrologic modelling and the hydraulic modelling occurs. This difficulty arises due to the differing problems for which a catchment modelling system may be employed. Furthermore, there is need for the catchment modelling system to be designed to suit the problem rather than the problem be modified to suit the catchment modelling system. The result is the hydrologic model component of the system will vary with alternative degrees of complexity required for different problems.

section.title: Scope
section.para: This book of Australian Rainfall and Runoff has been prepared to provide guidance on the background theory and practice associated with the hydrologic component of catchment modelling systems. Since catchments and the problems involved are diverse, and the related technology is changing, the recommendations on appropriate usage presented herein should not be taken as binding. They should be considered together with other information and local experience when being implemented.

The contents of this book within Australian Rainfall and Runoff are intended for a wide readership including engineers, students, technicians, surveyors and planners. Readers should be familiar with the basic concepts of catchment hydrology and hence have a basic knowledge of hydrology.

section.title: Terminology
section.para: Many terms associated with design flow estimation have been used in a loose manner, and sometimes quite incorrectly and in a misleading fashion. As outlined in Book 1, the National Committee on Water Engineering of Engineers Australia had three major concerns:

In view of the loose and frequently incorrect manner in which many terms often are used, it was considered that Australian Rainfall and Runoff should adopt terminology that is technically correct, as far as this is possible and in harmony with other objectives. Even if this terminology is not entirely popular with all users, it was considered that Engineers Australia has a responsibility to encourage and educate engineers regarding correct and consistent terminology. It was recognised also by the National Committee on Water Engineering that as well as being correct technically, the terms adopted should be relatively simple and suitable for use in practical design as this would facilitate acceptance by the profession.

section.title: Book Contents
section.para: There are five chapters within this book of Australian Rainfall and Runoff with the first chapter being an introduction to hydrologic estimation necessary for design flood prediction. Provided in the next chapter is a discussion of the alternative types of direct runoff models and the need for models enabling prediction of baseflow and losses. Each of these topics is then discussed in detail in the following chapters. In particular, alternative models for prediction of direct runoff and the relevant background to those models is presented in Chapter 3 together with recommendations on the usage of these models. In a similar manner, models for prediction of the baseflow occurring at the time of the flood event are presented in Chapter 4 while models for prediction of catchment losses during the flood event for both rural and urban catchments are presented in the final chapter.

Different to previous versions of Australian Rainfall and Runoff, in the development of this edition of Australian Rainfall and Runoff there has been an assumption that users will have computing resources available. The techniques presented in the following sections therefore require computing resources for their implementation. Therefore, the discussion in the following sections focusses on both the theoretical basis of the techniques and their implementation.
